critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Absence of code blocks is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification if no code blocks are present.
When in doubt, do NOT classify an element as a code block. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify regular prose or formatted text as code blocks unless they contain actual programming syntax.
Code blocks must contain recognizable programming constructs, configuration syntax, or command-line instructions.

code_block_definition.item: A code block is a section of text containing programming code, configuration data, or technical commands.
Code blocks typically appear in monospace fonts with distinctive formatting.
Code blocks often have syntax highlighting, line numbers, or bordered containers.
Code blocks contain recognizable programming constructs: keywords, operators, brackets, semicolons, etc.
Code blocks may include comments denoted by language-specific syntax (// # /* -- etc.).

language_identification.item: Python: indentation-based, def/class keywords, colons, no semicolons.
JavaScript/TypeScript: curly braces, function/const/let keywords, semicolons optional.
Java/C#: curly braces, class/public/private keywords, semicolons required.
HTML/XML: angle brackets, tag structure, attributes in quotes.
JSON: curly braces and brackets, key-value pairs with colons, quoted strings.
YAML: indentation-based, key-value with colons, dashes for lists.
SQL: SELECT/FROM/WHERE keywords, table and column references.
Shell/Bash: $ prompts, pipe operators, command flags with dashes.
CSS: selectors, curly braces, property: value pairs with semicolons.

not_code_blocks.item: Regular paragraphs of text are NOT code blocks, even if formatted differently.
Tables of data without programming syntax are NOT code blocks.
Mathematical formulas or equations are NOT code blocks.
Pseudocode without specific language syntax may or may not be a code block - use judgment.
File paths or URLs alone are NOT code blocks.
Keyboard shortcuts or menu paths are NOT code blocks.

pass_1_identification.step: Look for monospace font or distinctive code formatting.
Identify bordered containers or shaded backgrounds typical of code.
Look for line numbers in the margin.
Identify syntax highlighting (colored keywords, strings, comments).

pass_2_analysis.step: Verify presence of programming language constructs.
Identify the specific language based on syntax patterns.
Confirm the content is executable or parseable code, not prose.
Document the code structure and key elements.

decision_process.item: In the first pass, identify all potential code-like structures.
In the second pass, verify each potential code block contains actual programming syntax.
Consider the document context to avoid misclassification.
For verified code blocks, preserve exact formatting and content.
